I like how the S95F has the matte anti-reflective coating that can do an incredible job reducing the glare from windows or lights to the point that they're barely even visible. I'd eventually like to have one in 65" or 83" size but I had to settle with an LG G5 77" OLED evo AI for now since I found a good deal on fb marketplace and got one brand new in the box for $1000 bucks. I could barely afford that at the time after getting the water pump on my car replaced but it was well worth it coming from the 43" to 46" range.

Just changed my 55S90D for the 55S95F! We recently moved and the tv is in a game room/office. The S95F looks amazing in this bright office and even at night. Loved the S90D but the glare was annoying in my environment. I have grown to love the anti glare coating. In the loft, we have the 77S95D.

Great review of the Samsung S95F, really appreciate the detailed breakdown! I was seriously considering this model when shopping for a new TV, but in the end I went with the LG OLED evo G5 in 83 inches instead.

A few reasons why I chose the G5:

I watch a lot of content in Dolby Vision, and since the S95F only supports HDR10(+), Dolby Vision support on the G5 was a big plus for me. The 83-inch size also made the decision easier, since LG’s panel in that size delivers excellent uniformity, brightness, and black levels for movie-watching in a darker room. On top of that, having HDMI 2.1 on all four ports and very low input lag was huge, as I game on both console and PC. The wide viewing angles and overall picture consistency just sealed the deal for my setup.

That said, the S95F is still an awesome TV, especially for bright rooms thanks to the anti-reflection treatment, and your review definitely helped me think through the strengths of each option. But for my personal use case, the G5 just checked more boxes.

Thanks again for the solid review!

I have three Frame TV's and I have a mostly love and a little hate relationship with them.  I just bought a 65" LS03D at $1100.  The Samsung app and tv menus are terrible for all of them.  That is my hate portion of my experience.  I find that turning off or uninstalling the SamsungTV Plus app makes the tv menu work much better.  this is not a problem for me.  I don't know anyone that uses it.  I love the Art mode and most of my Frames stay in Art mode almost all the time.  I have other TV's for critical viewing, but I don't find the Frames to be bad for TV/Movie viewing.  I have the Deco custom Frames for my Samsung Frame TV's and they look fantastic.  Overall, I will continue to buy Frame TV's or TV's that are similar.  TCL and Hisense have similar TV's now.

To be quite honest and this is not a criticism to the reviewer...i don't get why people get these TVs and complain about the requirement for power...like which TV doesn't need power? if you get a TV like this and spend SO much $, you should probably read the manual first and then understand that you may have to get a contractor out to sort your electrical requirements out first so that it sits flush against wall etc. Any TV in the world will require power points at the back of the wall to give it a seamless and cable free look.  Regardless of whether the previous model allowed you to use just the one cable (which you would have to run through the wall anyway to make it look good), I would get powerpoints, HDMI port, and cable TV port setup on the wall behind where a TV goes if you wanted a neat look. That way, even if you change from the frame, you are already prepared and have everything ready to go. Sort out cable management first!

I know RTINGS don't get much into the marketing aspect of TVs, but it's worth mentioning that Samsung are marketing this as a true Mini-LED TV which is definitely false advertising as it is simply an Edge-LED backlight experience, with slightly smaller LEDs. Pretty much all Mini-LED features aren't present here, which makes it really non-compelling versus the standard 'The Frame' which also works/operates much better than the Pro variant. Worth seeing Snazzy Labs' video for more context on the vast issues facing this particular model. Arguably the worst buy of 2025.

Sony always said it best: it’s not about the number of zones, it’s about how you control them. That’s the real difference between a premium TV and the cheap marketing tricks some brands pull. Look closely at the so-called “Mini LED” sets from budget Sonys, LG, or Chinese brands like Hisense and TCL — in many cases, they’re not even using true mini LEDs at all. The diodes are often much larger than what’s considered standard, and since there’s no real industry regulation defining what counts as “mini,” manufacturers can stretch the label however they like.

At least SAMSUNG’s QLEDs are properly certified by independent German regulators, which means they’re actually meeting strict standards for quantum dot performance. The same can’t be said for certain other brands that slap the “QLED” name on a panel just because it happens to contain some quantum dots. That’s not quality — that’s marketing spin.

In this case, it’s a limitation of the tech. MicroLED is a breakthrough but it’s still hard to get them small enough and close enough to get smaller size displays. 115” not only hits a segment that wants bigger screens and cutting edge tech, but it conveniently allows them to ship something at the threshold of density they can hit.

Over time, as the tech matures, we will get smaller sizes. Ironically, smaller tech typically costs more initially because it requires the condensing of a lot of tech. Think of how computers used to take up an entire room and now you have one in your pocket.

Atualmente uso uma Samsung Q80A de 55” e estava aguardando os lançamentos da linha 2025. Me interessei bastante pela QN90F, mas fui informado pelo chat da própria Samsung que o modelo de 55” não será lançado no Brasil. Achei estranho, já que ele está disponível em outros mercados — segundo eles, por aqui haveria baixa demanda nesse tamanho, o que me surpreendeu, pois sempre considerei o 55” um dos tamanhos mais populares.

Assisti ao seu vídeo comparando a QN90F com a QN90D e entendi que, na sua opinião, a QN90D hoje é a melhor escolha, principalmente por conta do ângulo de visão. Mas queria tirar uma dúvida mais específica:

Meu uso é focado em filmes, séries e futebol (80%), e games (20%), com uma distância de visualização de 3,5 metros. Como o modelo de 55” da QN90F não virá, considerei a opção de pegar a QN90F de 50” por conta da tecnologia mais atual — principalmente o processador NQ4 AI Gen3, superior ao Gen2 presente na QN90D e QN85F.

Pensando apenas na tecnologia e na experiência de uso real (sem considerar ângulo de visão):

- Vale mais a pena optar pela QN90D de 55”, que é meu tamanho ideal,
ou
- A QN85F de 55” seria uma opção mais vantajosa do que a QN90D, mesmo sendo uma categoria abaixo?

Agradeço se puder comentar.

Muito bom essas dicas.

Configuração é algo pessoal, mas a sua sinceramente não me agrada. Eu nunca deixaria sombra em +1 nem gama em +1, prefiro 0 ou -1, pois assim o contraste fica mais equilibrado. O espaço de cor “Nativo” também não faz sentido, ele força a gama máxima do painel, deixando tudo super saturado e o verde bem artificial. O certo de acordo com o criador do conteudo é o Automático, que ajusta conforme o sinal (SDR, HDR, etc.) e mantém a fidelidade do Rec.709, DCI-P3 ou BT.2020. Outra coisa, otimizador de contraste em “Alto” é uma aberração, distorce completamente a imagem. E, por fim, sobre a tonalidade de cor, embora eu entenda você preferir o Padrão, no geral acho a Quente 1 mais natural e uso o Padrão só em conteúdos muito específicos.

Not every OLED is the same, especially considering the cheaper Samsung 84 models that are on sale. It’s important to know these TVs are great if you’re in a very dark room, but if you’re planning on putting one of these cheaper OLED in a bright family room I would strongly recommend not buying this..

Like I stated in the video you'll want to pay up for the QD-OLEDs or enhanced OLEDs if your room is bright, but for the most part I think OLED of any class should be bright enough for most rooms there are definitely cases where your room can be too bright for one of these entry level TVs but your going to have to really have a TV that is positioned opposite a window in that type of bright room scenario in this case.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

Hey KG, I know that Costco & Sam’s have the S85FD as their model-equivalent for the S85F. Not sure if the Best Buy version is an exact copy like they are, but in the 55” & 65” of the S85F & S85FD Samsung uses a QD-OLED panel. Do you know for sure that the S84 is different and not just the Best Buy, non price-matchable version, cause $899 would be a STEAL for a 65” QD-OLED. (And you know how I feel about QD-OLED😂🙄)

Also, I know you and I have gone back-and-forth on the whole LCD versus OLED/QD-OLED thing.😂 and maybe I have a fundamental misunderstanding, but isn’t SDR content stretched to the brightness that your TV is set at and capable of rather than compressed for accuracy like in HDR? So wouldn’t the tremendous increases in SDR brightness really help people who watch sports & other SDR content in bright rooms?

S85F is also QD OLED for non Costco models in those sizes. S84F is W OLED you can see by it ending in EXZA where QD OLED ends in FXZA here in the IS for its model number hopefully that helps clarify things more.

As for SDR brightness does have an advantage for LCDs in a bright room but it would only be needed if you’re room is ridiculously bright. Otherwise most people will not have their brightness maxed at SDR, even with an OLED you typically usually won’t want to go full brightness for SDR.
